messages: a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:35): as far as the parsing algorithm, an element with a plus sign in it is not an error, right?
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:36): In it? In the element name?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:37): e.g., <foo+bar>
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:37): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/tokenization.html#tag-name-state says it's not a parse error
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:37): or, rather, doesn't say it is a parse error
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:37): it shouldn't be a _parse_ error, no
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:38): 'course since there's no foo+bar element, it's still an error
a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (00:38): Right, that's a much more useful answer
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:50): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: (I do hope you're not planning to use + in an element name)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:51): ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c: I was asking in context of a message Jonathan Rees posted to www-tag yesterday
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:54): http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2009Nov/0015.html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:55): this part:
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:55): For example, one might say that addition of new elements and
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:55): attributes is likely to happen, but not changes in the lexical syntax
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:55): such as the addition of something like <% .... %> or allowing + in
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:55): element names.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (00:58): seems like he was stating that as a example of a type of syntax restriction

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:00): maybe part of the answer should be, there are no existing arbitrary syntax restrictions like that -- instead there are only things that generate parse errors and things that are do not
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:00): there are some arbitrary restrictions
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:00): like unquoted attributes can't contain `
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:00): because of potential security problems with IE
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:00): I see
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:01): so maybe I can make up a list of those
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:02): that seems in part at least to be what he's wondering about
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:02): that is, the bounds on what can be changed in the syntax and what can't be
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:04): i dunno
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:04): we can probably add new syntax
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:04): it'd just be somewhat painful
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:05): and we can add anything that is currently a bogus comment pretty easily
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:05): e.g. we could add <% ... %> so long as "..." can never be ">"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): we could add <!start range selection> ... <!end range selection>
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): so other things like that

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:06): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I realize the first two points. but it seems like things such as the restriction on unquoted attribute values containing ' that really can't be changed practically changed at this point
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): unquoted attribute values only can't contain ' because it's confusing
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:07): eh? I thought you just said it was an IE security issue?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): that's `
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): not '
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:08): needs to get better fonts.. or bigger ones.. or better eyes
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:09): a lot of these restrictions are there purely for compatibility with xml
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:10): if it wasn't for staying roughly compatible with xml, we could make some pretty good changes
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): so maybe it could help if I wrote up an informational document about those
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): unless somebody else already has
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:10): on the wiki or somewhere
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:11): help how?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:11): Help who?
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:12): (Oh, are there really no more anagrams for "how"? :-( )
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:12): help people who want to put together documents that are going to be processing as they'd expect without having side effects they don't want
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): i don't follow
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:12): e.g, the reason why you should not put an XML declaration in a document served as text/html
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:13): well, one of the reasons
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:13): the most important one being that it will put IE6 into quirks mode
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:13): most people don't know that
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:13): isn't that basically the only reason?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:13): or don't remember it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:14): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I guess another reason would be that it doesn't otherwise have any effect
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:14): e.g., if you try to use it set encoding, it's not going to do anything

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:14): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Like a subset of HTML5's conformance criteria, but only for compatibility concerns, ignoring all the issues of good taste and readability and accessibility and whatever?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:14): yeah, pretty much
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:15): just listing things that are "gotchas", I guess
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:15): I occasionally get questions about this kind of stuff off-list
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: then there's a lot of other crap we should make illegal :-)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): like xmlns=""
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): and /?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): er />
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:16): well, yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): the only reason they're allowed is to make polyglots possible
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): though personally i wish we could go in the other direction
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): far, far in the other direction

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:17): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: I know but that position seems to be out of sync with the range of authors/content providers who say they want to do it and seem to feel pretty strongly about it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:18): most of them think that they're doing stuff simple enough that it won't be a problem
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): and i think (a) they're likely to either be wrong already or soon will be, and (b) they are misleading others into thinking they are in a similar situation
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:19): I don't know about most but I am sure many

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:19): those who don't think they're doing stuff simple enough that it won't be a problem are unlikely to want to do it, since by definition they think they'd have a problem :-)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:20): I think point (b) is the more important one
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:21): the xml/html dichotomy is worse than the c/C++ dichotomy

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:21): perhaps we should require that people who believe they know what they are doing should include a disclaimer in their content along the lines of "Trained professional driver. Don't try this as home."
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:21): of course then others would just cargo-cult copy that disclaimer too
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:22): we clearly need some certification/regulation here
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:23): what we have now is more kinda like the gun-control (or lack of gun-control) situation in the US
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): sam's the only person whose source i have examined whom i know has done this seriously enough to really be considered a train professional driver
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): and he recommends against it
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:23): right
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:23): but i'm tired of arguing this point, if people want to do it, then fine
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:24): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:24): so to get back to the context for my original question, my motivation is just my own general laziness
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:24): Don't bother with certification, just make the technology as complex as possible then charge people $1500 for a three-day course on it
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:24): Saves all the effort of printing proper certificates
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:25): yeah, that seems to be working well for a lot of technologies/standards
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:25): we must raise the barrier for entry
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:25): make it much more painful
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:25): people learn best from pain
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:26): I know I do

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:28): anyway, I would just rather be able to point people to "list of stuff that you really should not be doing even though you think it should be OK" doc instead of answering (or attempting to answer) the same kinds of questions in private e-mail repeatedly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:30): or instead of people using reading docs like http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml-media-types/ and assuming they actually reflect real-world best practices
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:32): I can see that there are sections of that doc that simon pointed out specific problems with more than a year ago but for which no changes were ever made
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (01:33): apologizes for the monologue
